questions.text: A 50 yrs male came to the hospital with a known case of hypertension after ten years of treatment. His ECG is shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left ventricular hypertrophy Option A. Left ventricular hypertrophy: in the above ECG, the s wave in v1 plus the r wave in v5 or v6 is greater than 35 mm, lvh is present. Hence, the above ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 35 yrs female with a known case of primary pulmonary hypertension, she underwent ECG, which is shown below: What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Right ventricular hypertrophy Right ventricular hypertrophy: in the above case there is the presence of a R/S ratio of greater than 1 in lead V1 and the R wave in lead V1 is greater than 7 millimeters tall. Hence, the above ECG is of right ventricular tachycardia.

Highyeild:

CRITERION FOR RIGHT VENTRICULAR HYPERTROPHY: RVH is diagnosed on ECG in the presence of a R/S ratio of greater than 1 in lead V1 in the absence of other causes, or if the R wave in lead V1 is greater than 7 millimeters tall . The strain pattern occurs when the right ventricular wall is quite thick, and the pressure is high, as well. Strain causes ST segment depression and asymmetric T wave inversions in leads V1 to V3.
